stem: A 28-year-old client with a T4 spinal cord injury (SCI) reports a sudden, throbbing headache. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
SITUATION: At 15:00, a 28-year-old male with a T4 spinal cord injury is experiencing a hypertensive crisis. The client reports a severe, throbbing headache and blurred vision. Initial blood pressure is 210/115 mmHg, and heart rate is 52 bpm. The client appears anxious and restless.

BACKGROUND: The client sustained a complete T4 SCI three years ago and is currently admitted to the rehabilitation unit for routine follow-up and therapy. The client has an indwelling urinary catheter.

ASSESSMENT: The client's skin is flushed and diaphoretic above the T4 level, while the skin below is cool and pale. A distended bladder is noted upon palpation. The urinary catheter was found kinked at 14:15 and has been resolved.

RECOMMENDATION: Immediately assess for any other potential noxious stimuli, elevate the head of the bed, and closely monitor blood pressure and heart rate. Consider pharmacological intervention if blood pressure remains elevated after addressing potential triggers.

tabs.title: Nursing Notes
tabs.content: 14:00 - Client reported difficulty with indwelling catheter drainage. 14:15 - Catheter found to be kinked under the wheelchair frame. Kink resolved. 14:20 - BP increased rapidly.

actionOptions.text: Immediately elevate the head of the bed (HOB) to 90 degrees
Check the urinary catheter for kinks or distention
Place the client in a flat, supine position
Perform a digital rectal exam immediately

parameterOptions.text: Mental status and orientation every 4 hours

rationale.correct: Autonomic Dysreflexia (AD) (c2) is a potentially life-threatening condition that occurs in individuals with spinal cord injuries at or above the T6 level. It is triggered by noxious stimuli below the level of the injury. In this case, the kinked urinary catheter and subsequent bladder distention send signals that the body cannot regulate due to the SCI. This results in a massive sympathetic nervous system discharge, leading to severe hypertension. The brain attempts to compensate via the parasympathetic nervous system, resulting in bradycardia, flushing, and sweating above the level of injury. The priority is to reduce blood pressure by elevating the head of the bed to 90 degrees (a1) to promote orthostatic hypotension and to identify and remove the noxious stimulus, such as checking for catheter kinks or bladder distention (a2). Continuous monitoring of blood pressure (p1) and heart rate (p2) is crucial, as uncontrolled hypertension can lead to stroke, seizure, or death.
clinicalPearls: Common triggers for AD include bladder distention (most common), bowel impaction, pressure ulcers, tight clothing, or even minor procedures.
The mnemonic 'Up, Loosen, Look' can help guide nursing actions: Elevate the head of the bed, loosen any constrictive clothing, and look for the underlying cause.
Flushing, diaphoresis, and nasal congestion typically occur ABOVE the level of injury, while pallor and goosebumps occur BELOW.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting 'Perform a digital rectal exam immediately' (a4) without addressing the more immediate and potentially reversible cause of bladder distention.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize interventions based on the immediacy of the threat. While bowel impaction is a common cause, addressing the kinked catheter is the priority.

mnemonic.title: AD Response
mnemonic.expansion: Head of bed UP. Bladder Check. Bowel Check.
